Identification_Area.title: Apollo 17 Surface Electrical Properties Experiment Calibrated ASCII Data Bundle

Citation_Information.description: This bundle contains two comma-delimited ASCII files of calibrated lunar surface electromagnetic field and navigation (range) data from the Surface Electrical Properties (SEP) Experiment at the Apollo 17 landing site for the time span of 11-13 December 1972. One file contains straightened science and navigation (range) data; the other file contains only unstraightened science data. These data were extracted from binary files held on magnetic tape at the NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive as data set PSPG-00559, then reformatted to ASCII. This bundle also contains a high-resolution digital reproduction of the SEP final technical report that contains plots of the complete set of processed lunar field data, as decibal values versus range, and explanations the data processing and calibration techniques implemented by the SEP instrument team.

Modification_Detail.description: Creation. Revised Oct/Nov 2019 to include the SEP data collection.

Primary_Result_Summary.description: Calibrated lunar electromagnetic science data and navigation (range) data from the Surface Electrical Properties (SEP) Experiment at the Apollo 17 landing site for the time span of 11-13 December 1972, along with a high-resolution digital reproduction of the SEP final technical report that contains plots of the complete set of processed lunar field data, as decibal values versus range. The SEP experiment consisted o two stationary, orthogonal, electric dipole transmitting antennae laid on the lunar surface near the Lunar Module and a wide-bandwidth, mutually-perpendicular, three-component receiver antenna mounted on the Lunar Roving Vehicle which traversed away from the transmitting receiver with the purpose of obtaining data about electromagnetic energy transmission, absorption, and reflection characteristics of the lunar regolith. Comparisons of the transmitted and received signals at frequencies of 1, 2.1, 4, 8.1, 16, and 32 MHz were used to determine layering, search for pressure of water below the surface, and measure electrical properties in situ, all as a function of depth.
